issue.title: input with two values

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This is a duplicate issue or root-cause of another issue

repository.name: jsoup
repository.description: jsoup: the Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing, cleaning, scraping, and XSS safety.

issue.body:
I've encountered an input field (type hidden) with two value attributes, such as:
`<input name="test" value="foo" type="hidden" value="bar"/>`
When I submit the form in a browser, the first value gets submitted ("foo" in this case) - tested with Chromium and Firefox.
But when I parse the html with jsoup, the element gets the second value ("bar" in this case), overriding the first one.

body:
That's the place for a fix: https://github.com/jhy/jsoup/blob/7ff7c43e9fbf4bbaf2b4517b3d4f8a429d87d3bb/src/main/java/org/jsoup/parser/Token.java#L128
Let's just keep the first attribute value and drop the next one without raising an error. I will try to implement it soon.

> When the user agent leaves the attribute name state (and before emitting the tag token, if appropriate), the complete attribute's name must be compared to the other attributes on the same token; if there is already an attribute on the token with the exact same name, then this is a parse error and the new attribute must be dropped, along with the value that gets associated with it (if any).

https://dev.w3.org/html5/pf-summary/syntax.html#attribute-name-state

issue.title: Bump jsoup from 1.12.1 to 1.12.2

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

repository.name: stub-idp
repository.description: Identity Provider and eIDAS Proxy Node

issue.body:
Bumps [jsoup](https://github.com/jhy/jsoup) from 1.12.1 to 1.12.2.
Changelog

Sourced from jsoup's changelog.

jsoup changelog

*** Release 1.13.1 [PENDING]

  • Improvement: when pretty-printing, comments in inline tags are not pushed to a newline

  • Removed old methods and classes that were marked deprecated in previous releases.

**** Release 1.12.2 [2020-Feb-08]

  • Improvement: the :has() selector now supports relative selectors. For example, the query "div:has(> a)" will select all "div" elements that have at least one direct child "a" element. jhy/jsoup#1214

  • Bugfix: in a
